Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Amplified Ultrashort Pulse Laser for Imaging and Spectroscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This MRI acquisition will establish the first amplified ultrashort pulse laser facility for spectroscopy and energy science in the Four Corners region of the United States. The facility will be based at Fort Lewis College (FLC) in Durango, Colorado. The acquisition of this instrument will significantly boost the research and teaching capacity of the proposing investigators, the college and the region. This acquisition will directly increase the participation of underrepresented groups in scientific research. FLC is a Native American serving institution and ranks fourth in the nation in percentage of full-time Native American undergraduates but first in baccalaureate degrees and second in STEM degrees awarded to Native Americans. FLC students, along with students from collaborating schools (i.e., Colorado Mesa University and San Juan College) will perform research in a state-of-the-art facility. This acquisition will vastly improve the research infrastructure of the region in addition to facilitating closer ties with local industry, regional laboratories and colleges. This impact will extend to students throughout the region, and the community as a whole will benefit from a better prepared and diverse workforce. Finally, data generated will be disseminated to the wider research community leading to a lasting impact on the knowledge in spray breakup processes, nuclear cooling, energy transfer and liquid phase molecular dynamics and other research planned for the instrument.

Ultrashort pulse amplified laser systems have evolved into robust, turnkey systems capable of generating coherent pulses with several millijoules of energy and, when combined with an optical parametric amplifier, wavelength ranges from the ultraviolet to the infrared. Ultrashort laser pulses provide unprecedented temporal resolution for a wide range of applications within biology, chemistry, engineering, and materials science. Many fundamental physical processes occur during ultrafast time scales, and ultrashort pulsed lasers have created a host of new and innovative ways of investigating such processes. This laser facility will be used in research programs focusing on combustion and propulsion science, Generation IV nuclear reactors, the dynamics of liquid phase molecular energy transfer, photoluminescence and surface morphology of porous silicon, laser patterning, laser assisted deposition, characterization of photovoltaic materials, photothermal therapeutics, materials characterization, and the development of innovative microscopy capabilities at Fort Lewis College. This award is co-funded by the CBET Division and CMMI Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first ultrashort pulse laser facility for spectroscopy, cell biology and energy science has been established in the Four Corners region of the United States. The facility is based at Fort Lewis College (FLC) in Durango, Colorado  significantly boosting the research and teaching capacity of faculty at Fort Lewis College, collaborators and the region.  

Equipment procured and installed in the ultrashort laser facility at Fort Lewis College includes: a Spectra-Physics Solstice Ace regeneratively amplified Ti:Sapphire laser, a TOPAS optical parametric amplifier (OPA) in combination with a NIRUVIS wavelength extender, a Scientifica multi photon microscope and a Newport transient absorption spectrometer. The Solstice Ace is capable of producing 5 mJ of energy per pulse at a 1 kHz repetition rate; the energy is divided with half entering the OPA while the remainder enters an external compressor. The TOPAS/NIRUVIS  is capable of converting the laser pulse centered at an 800 nm wavelength beam down to 220 nm and up to 2 microns. The Scientifica microscope uses the Solstice oscillator beam with a bandwidth based on the Ti:Sapphire gain bandwidth; therefore, multiphoton fluorophore excitations from 300 to 500 nm are possible. All systems are operational and have been utilized by both Fort Lewis faculty as well as visiting faculty in combustion, materials science and chemical kinetics research.

The broader impact of funding this MRI proposal are multiple. Firstly, funding this proposal has had a direct impact on participation of underrepresented groups in scientific research. As a federally designated Native American-Serving, Non-Tribal institution with an historic mission to educate the nation's Native Americans within a liberal arts framework, FLC is at the forefront of increasing representation of Native Americans in the STEM fields.  FLC ranks 4th in the nation in percent of full-time Native American undergraduates but first in baccalaureate STEM degrees awarded to Native Americans. The FLC student population is just under 3000 with approximately 50% minority students, and this is mirrored in the STEM departments. Over the past 2 years, 15 underrepresented students have directly participated in undergraduate research activities as a result of this funding. These students have had the opportunity to perform research in a state-of-the-art facility and at least 6 of these students have gone on to perform research at R1 institutions during the summer of 2019. The feedback received from faculty at these institutions has been extremely positive. Furthermore, 2 participants are currently in graduate school. Secondly, funding this proposal has significantly improved the research infrastructure of FLC and the region which will continue to facilitate closer ties with local industry, regional laboratories and colleges. The community as a whole will benefit from a better prepared and diverse workforce. Thirdly, data generated is currently being prepared for two publications and has been presented at several conferences.
